title: Getting Started with HTML: A Beginner's Guide

content.text: HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language. It is the standard language used to create web pages. HTML uses 'tags' to structure the content on a web page, allowing browsers to display text, images, and other elements correctly. Every web page you see is made up of HTML code.
content.code_example:
Hello, World!

This is my first web page created using HTML!

mcq_questions.question: What does HTML stand for?
options: B) Hyperlink and Text Markup Language

content.text:
HTML is made up of elements that are defined using tags. Tags are keywords surrounded by angle brackets, like . Most tags come in pairs: an opening tag and a closing tag. The content goes between these tags. For example,

This is a paragraph.

creates a paragraph.
content.code_example:
This is a Heading

This is a paragraph of text.

mcq_questions.question: Which of the following correctly represents a paragraph in HTML?

content.text: HTML allows you to organize your content using various tags. Headings are defined with <h1> to <h6>, where <h1> is the largest and <h6> is the smallest. You can also use <div> to group related content together, helping to keep your code organized.
content.code_example:
My Blog Post

This is the introduction of my blog post.

This paragraph is part of a div, used to group related content.

mcq_questions.question: What is the purpose of a <div> tag in HTML?
options: B) To create a division or section in a document

content.text: You can create two types of lists in HTML: ordered lists (<ol>) and unordered lists (<ul>). Ordered lists use numbers for each item, while unordered lists use bullet points. Both lists contain list items, which are defined with the <li> tag.

mcq_questions.question: Which tag is used to create an ordered list in HTML?
